head.title: Influence of the Reaction Pathway on the Defect Formation in a Cu2ZnSnSe4 Thin Film | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Influence of the Reaction Pathway on the Defect Formation in a Cu2ZnSnSe4 Thin Film

Point defect engineering in Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) thin films is the main issue to improve its device performance. This study reveals the correlation between the reaction pathway and the point defects in the CZTSe film. The reaction pathway from a metallic precursor (Mo/Zn/Sn/Cu) to a kesterite CZTSe film is varied by changing the annealing process. The synthesized CZTSe films under different reaction pathways induce different device performances with different defect energy levels, although all CZTSe films have similar structural and optical properties (Eg ∼ 1.0 eV). The admittance spectroscopy demonstrates the correlations between point defect types (VZn, ZnSn, ZnCu, CuZn, and VCu) and the reaction pathways for the formation of CZTSe films. The different growth rates of binary selenides, such as ZnSe and/or Sn–Se phases, during the annealing process are especially strongly related to the formation of point defects, leading to the different open-circuit voltages (396–451 mV) and fill factors (51–65%). The results of this study suggest that controlling the reaction pathway is an effective approach to adjust the formation of defects in the kesterite CZTSe film as well as to fabricate high-performance solar cell devices.

div.p:
Point defect engineering in Cu
2
ZnSnSe
4
(CZTSe) thin films is the main issue to improve its device performance. This study reveals the correlation between the reaction pathway and the point defects in the CZTSe film. The reaction pathway from a metallic precursor (Mo/Zn/Sn/Cu) to a kesterite CZTSe film is varied by changing the annealing process. The synthesized CZTSe films under different reaction pathways induce different device performances with different defect energy levels, although all CZTSe films have similar structural and optical properties (
E
g
∼ 1.0 eV). The admittance spectroscopy demonstrates the correlations between point defect types (V
Zn
, Zn
Sn
, Zn
Cu
, Cu
Zn
, and V
Cu
) and the reaction pathways for the formation of CZTSe films. The different growth rates of binary selenides, such as ZnSe and/or Sn–Se phases, during the annealing process are especially strongly related to the formation of point defects, leading to the different open-circuit voltages (396–451 mV) and fill factors (51–65%). The results of this study suggest that controlling the reaction pathway is an effective approach to adjust the formation of defects in the kesterite CZTSe film as well as to fabricate high-performance solar cell devices.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Kesterite Cu
2
ZnSnSe
4
(CZTSe) is a promising material for applications in thin-film solar cells. Recently, Son et al. have achieved a world record efficiency of 12.62%,
(1)
demonstrating the potential of this material using a sputtered precursor and post-annealing approaches. However, kesterite materials have performance limitations due to their large open-circuit voltage (
V
oc
) deficit compared with Cu(In,Ga)Se
2
and CdTe materials for the thin-film solar cells.
(1−5)
To overcome this problem, an algorithm for the formation of defects in the absorber layer has been theoretically and experimentally studied in relation to the chemical composition (cation ratios) of the kesterite phase.
(5−11)
Chen et al. theoretically calculated the energy levels and formation energies of all the defects in Cu
2
ZnSnS
4
(CZTS) and CZTSe thin films dependent on the cation ratios and Fermi energies.
(6)
Gurieva et al. also experimentally demonstrated the existence of different defect types depending on the composition ratios of [Cu]/([Zn] + [Sn]) and [Zn]/[Sn].
(7)
However, the influence of a reaction pathway of the kesterite phase on defect formation has not yet been studied, although it is already speculated by several researchers.
(5,6,12)
Because the point defects in the kesterite absorbers are determined by chemical potentials and because the chemical potentials can be different depending on the annealing conditions, it is necessary to study the influence of the reaction pathway on the formation of point defects in a CZTSe absorber.

In fact, the formation pathways for the formation of kesterite thin films have been studied
(12−22)
by changing the sequence of metallic layers in the precursor
(13−16)
or by using only one type of annealing process.
(1,12,17−21)
These previous studies, however, typically focus on the reason for the presence of secondary phases and/or on the formation mechanism of the kesterite absorbers. The previously reported literature studies show that there are two ways to evolve a kesterite CZTSe phase: (i) by combining Cu
2
Se, ZnSe, and SnSe
2
(and/or SnSe) or (ii) by compounding Cu
2
SnSe
3
and ZnSe. In the case of Cu
2
SnSe
3
, this phase can also be formed in two ways: by combining CuSe and SnSe (and/or SnSe
2
) or CuSe
2
and SnSe (and/or SnSe
2
).
(11,18,19,22)
As a result, there are three ways to synthesize a CZTSe phase, as described below. In the case of the Sn–Se phase, some researchers use SnSe in the equation for the reaction pathway of CZTSe, whereas some other researchers use SnSe
2
instead of SnSe in the similar equation. For this reason, here the equations described below are organized without distinction of the Sn–Se phase.
(11,18,19,22)

These three equations signify that the reaction pathway for the formation of the CZTSe phase can be distinguished by the Cu–Se phase. Here, the formation of the Cu–Se phase can be easily controlled by supplying different annealing temperatures in accordance with the peritectic temperatures of the Cu–Se phases,
(23)
which means that if the temperature of the first step in a two-step annealing process is varied from 300 to 400 °C, as described in
Figure
1
, the Cu–Se phase will form differently, inducing different reaction pathways. The expected Cu–Se phases and related reaction pathways in different temperature ranges are described in
Table
1
. According to this theory, four different annealing processes are prepared to vary the reaction pathways and are performed on the same precursor. Then, solar cell devices are fabricated at the same time and are used to analyze the defect energy levels. The results of this study reveal that the reaction pathway significantly influences not only the formation of point defects in the CZTSe absorber but also the device performance.

div.p: Figure 1. Schematic of the one-step (a) and two-step (b) annealing processes. The one-step process for sample A1 only has a HT stage, whereas the two-step process for samples A2 (LT = 300 °C), A3 (LT = 350 °C), and A4 (LT = 400 °C) has LT and HT stages. Points p1, p2, and p3 indicate the beginning and the end of each stage for each annealing process.

The Cu–Se phases per temperatures are determined on the basis of the Cu–Se phase diagram.
(23)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: Precursors were prepared on a Mo-coated glass with a sequence of Mo/Zn/Sn/Cu by using the direct current (DC) sputtering technique. The total thickness of the precursor was ∼580 nm, and its composition ratio was Cu-poor and Zn-rich, with values of 0.73 for [Cu]/([Zn] + [Sn]) and 1.39 for [Zn]/[Sn], as measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). The prepared precursor was placed in a graphite box with selenium (Se) powder (0.2 g) and then heated using halogen lamps under an Ar atmosphere.

To investigate the influence of the reaction pathway for the formation of the CZTSe film on device performance, one-step and two-step annealing processes were employed, as described in
Figure
1
. A one-step process was performed on sample A1 and has one dwelling stage at 490 °C for 10 min. The complete stage for the one-step process is termed as the “high-temperature (HT) stage” in this study. The two-step annealing process has an additional annealing stage [termed as the “low-temperature (LT) stage”] at temperatures lower than 490 °C for 5 min and then followed the HT stage. An additional annealing stage, the LT stage, was performed at 300, 350, and 400 °C for samples A2, A3, and A4, respectively, in accordance with
Table
1
. The temperature was increased at a rate of 2.5 °C s
–1
for all annealing processes, measured on the right-hand side of the graphite box using a thermocouple. The graphite box is divided into two pieces, one for a container and another for a cover. The overall shape of it is cuboid with a size of 10.8 × 6.0 × 2.2 cm
3
(
W
×
L
×
H
), and the bottom thickness of the container, where the sample is located, is ∼7 mm. The thicknesses for the side of the container and the cover are the same with ∼3 mm. All the annealing processes proceeded under an Ar atmosphere inside the quartz tube. After finishing the process, the graphite box naturally cooled down. The composition ratios of four CZTSe films are shown with similar values of ∼0.7 for [Cu]/([Zn] + [Sn]) and ∼1.3 for [Zn]/[Sn], as measured by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The exact values of the composition ratios of the four CZTSe films and a precursor are described in
Table S1
.

After completing the annealing processes, the fabrication processes for the solar cell devices were performed simultaneously for the four CZTSe films. A cadmium sulfide (CdS) layer (∼40 nm) was deposited on the CZTSe films using a chemical bath deposition approach at 60 °C for 14.5 min.
(24)
Then, intrinsic zinc oxide (∼100 nm) and aluminum-doped ZnO (Al:ZnO) (∼660 nm) layers were sequentially deposited using a radio frequency sputtering technique.
(24)
The aluminum layer was used as a grid on top of the solar cell device and placed using DC sputtering. An antireflection coating was not applied in all devices. The same processes were performed three times, which is termed “three series” in this study, and all the device parameters for each sample from the three series are described in
Figure S1
.

The formed phases at each point of each sample were revealed using high-resolution X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy. XRD measurements (X’Pert PRO, Philips) were performed on the annealed films with the same size, using a goniometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 154 pm), operating at 40 kV and 30 mA. Raman spectroscopy [Jobin-Yvon T64000, HORIBA, at Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI)] was performed using a 515 nm laser with a ∼2.5 mW output power and 1800 grooves mm
–1
grating. In this study, Raman measurements were performed at three different parts of the sample surface taken at each point of the annealing process because one Raman spectrum does not represent all the phases for the whole sample area. Raman spectra were collected three times with an exposure time of 30 s. The band gaps of the CZTSe films were measured using photoluminescence (PL, C12132, Hamamatsu) using a 532 nm laser with a power of ∼1.3 mW at room temperature. To confirm the composition ratios of the annealed CZTSe thin films, EDS attached to field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JSM-6701F, Jeol, at KBSI) with an accelerating voltage of 20 kV was performed. The composition ratio of the precursor was separately confirmed using ICP-OES (Optima 8300, Perkin Elmer, at KBSI). The device performances of the four samples were compared using current density–voltage (
J
–
V
) and external quantum efficiency (EQE) measurements. The
J
–
V
curve was measured under air mass 1.5 G (100 mW cm
–2
) using a class AAA solar simulator (WXS-155S-L2, Wacom), and EQE (S-9230, SOMA Optics) was performed using a spectral response measuring system. To reveal the defect energy levels in the CZTSe films, admittance spectroscopy (AS) measurements were performed with the Cp-D mode in the temperature range of 100–300 K under dark conditions using an LCR meter (E4980A, Agilent), and the applied alternating current frequency was varied from 100 Hz to 2 MHz.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 3.1. Reaction Pathways for the CZTSe Film Formation
div.div:
Four types of annealing processes are shown with the different reaction pathways for the formation of the CZTSe film. The reaction pathways for the four samples are confirmed by observation of the formed phases during the annealing process at points p1, p2, and p3, as described in
Figure
1
, on the basis of the reaction mechanism between the Cu–Zn–Sn–Se components.
(1,15−22,25)
The formed phases at each point of the annealing process are determined by the XRD patterns and Raman spectra, as described in
Figure
2
, and are organized in
Table
2
. The Raman spectrum for A2-p1 is not shown in
Figure
2
g because the annealed film for A2-p1 consists of only metallic alloys without any chalcogenides.

div.p:
Figure 2. XRD patterns (left side) and the corresponding Raman spectra (right side) of samples A1 (a,b), A2 (c,d), A3 (e,f), and A4 (g,h) taken at points p1, p2, and p3 during the annealing process, as described in
Figure
1
. In the case of the Raman spectra, three different parts of the film surface are measured from one sample, which is taken at each annealing point.

div.p: These phases signify trace amounts of the phases in the films.
These phases are detected only from the Raman spectrum, not from XRD patterns.

CZTSe with Cu

div.div:
The CZTSe film for sample A1 is formed from Cu
2
Se, ZnSe, and SnSe
2
(or SnSe), following
eq 1
, as described in
Figure
2
a,b. As the precursor is directly heated from 20 to 490 °C, some metals and/or metallic alloys of the precursor do not react with Se and remain as Cu
5
Zn
8
, Zn, and Cu
6
Sn
5
at point p1 (A1-p1). In the meantime, the other metallic elements react with Se, mainly compounding into ZnSe and CZTSe phases. It means that the Cu
2
Se and SnSe
2
phases grow too slowly in comparison with the formation of ZnSe. For this reason, the peaks for Cu
2
Se and SnSe
2
phases are observed only in the Raman spectrum for A1-p1 but are not detected in the XRD patterns (
Figure
2
a,b). Here, it is worth noticing that the ZnSe phase is not directly used to form CZTSe but remains in combination with CZTSe, and the Raman peak intensities of the ZnSe and CZTSe phases are similar (
Figure
2
b). After 10 min, marked by A1-p3, the kesterite CZTSe phase is fully formed in the film.

The formation of the kesterite CZTSe film for sample A2 starts with metallic Cu–Zn, Sn–Zn, and Cu
6
Sn
5
alloys and less ZnSe, but the reaction pathway is unclear. Considering the free energy for the formation of binary selenides and the affinity of reactions between Cu–Zn–Sn–Se (Sn–Se < Cu–Se < Zn–Se), one thing is certain: the Sn–Se phase is formed after the formation of the Cu–Se and Zn–Se phases in the film.
(1,15−17,22,25)
The CuSe
2
phase is not compounded during the LT stage, different from
Table
1
, due to the formation of the Cu–Zn alloy prior to complete vaporization of the Se powder. According to the literature,
(16,22)
the reaction temperature between Se and Cu (or Zn) from the Cu–Zn alloy increases as the Cu at. % in the Cu–Zn alloy increases.
(17,22)
Similarly, the increase of Cu concentration in the Cu–Zn alloy during the LT stage is observed in sample A2. The peaks for Cu
5
Zn
8
at ∼35 and ∼38° (solid orange inverted triangles) in
Figure
2
c for A2-p1 are vanished at point p2 (A2-p2), indicating the transition of the Cu
5
Zn
8
phase (A2-p1) into the relatively Cu-rich Cu–Zn (Cu
rich
Zn) alloy (A2-p2) during the LT stage. For this reason, the Cu from the Cu–Zn alloy cannot react with Se at 300 °C. The observation of metallic Sn at 300 °C is understandable in consideration of the formation of the eutectic Sn–Zn alloy.
(1,17,22,26)

Sample A3 clearly shows that the CZTSe film is formed from the CuSe, SnSe
(2)
, and ZnSe, following
eq 2
, as described in
Table
1
. In addition, the CZTSe phase is detected in one of the Raman spectra (light purple color) in A3-p2 at 350 °C. During the LT stage, the Cu–Zn alloy transforms into the ZnSe and CuSe phases, which can be inferred by observing the decreasing peak intensity of the Cu–Zn phase at ∼43° (
Figure
2
e) from A3-p1 to A3-p2. However, the ZnSe phase is not detected in the Raman spectrum for A3-p2 (
Figure
2
f), whereas it is found in the Raman spectrum for A3-p1. Differently from the Raman spectra, the XRD pattern in A3-p1 has no peak for the ZnSe phase located at ∼27°, suggesting that a small amount of ZnSe has already formed at the beginning of the LT stage. Then, the formed ZnSe is covered by other binary selenides, such as Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases.
(17,21)
For this reason, the metallic Zn and/or ZnSe phases remain on a lower part of the film at A3-p2 (see
Figure S2
for details) and then react with other Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases, finally forming the kesterite CZTSe.

Sample A4 shows the dominant formation of the CZTSe phase in the film at point p2 (A4-p2) following
eq 1
. Cu–Zn, Sn–Zn, and Cu
6
Sn
5
alloys with a small amount of ZnSe at point p1 (A4-p1) are transformed mostly into a kesterite CZTSe at point p2 (A4-p2) during the LT stage, as described in
Figure
2
g,h. The peaks for SnSe
2
(solid blue diamonds) are also detected in the XRD patterns and the Raman spectra for A4-p2. Weak diffractions at ∼42.9 and ∼44.2° for the Cu
2–
x
Zn and Cu
2–
x
Se phases are evidence for the formation of ZnSe along with Cu
2–
x
Se from the Cu–Zn alloy during the LT stage (see
Figure S3
for A4-p2). According to the previous results,
(15,16,22)
when the Cu–Zn alloy reacts with Se, ZnSe forms first, and the remaining Cu–Zn alloy becomes Cu
rich
Zn. Then, the Cu from Cu
rich
Zn reacts with Se, forming Cu
2
Se at a temperature higher than ∼380 °C.
(15,16,22)
ZnSe can also be formed from the eutectic Sn–Zn alloy.
(1,22)
This finding means that the ZnSe phase steadily forms from the Cu–Zn and Sn–Zn alloys, simultaneously with the formation of Cu
2–x
Se and SnSe
2
phases during the LT stage. Due to the fast growth of the Cu
2–
x
Se and SnSe
2
phases, ZnSe can directly combine with the Cu
2–
x
Se and SnSe
2
phases to form CZTSe, following
eq 1
, as soon as ZnSe forms. Then, the annealed film for A4-p2 crystallizes into the kesterite CZTSe during the HT stage.

Interestingly, the reaction pathway for the formation of the CZTSe film for sample A4 seems to be similar to that of sample A1. The amount of selenide phases before the formation of the kesterite CZTSe phase in samples A1 and A4 are, however, somewhat different, indicating different reaction pathways. As previously mentioned, the compounded ZnSe phase at A1-p1 cannot be directly used to form CZTSe due to the slow growth of Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases and the relatively fast growth of the ZnSe phase. Contrary to sample A1, a small amount of the ZnSe phase in A4-p1 can be directly combined with Cu
2–
x
Se and SnSe
2
to form the kesterite CZTSe phase during the LT stage. Considering the high stability of the ZnSe phase, it is obvious that a certain amount of the ZnSe phase in A1-p1 combines into the kesterite CZTSe phase later than that in A4-p1.
(25)
The growth rate of Cu–Se, ZnSe, and Sn–Se phases induces the different point defects in the kesterite film, which will be discussed in detail in
Section 3.4
.

div.h3: 3.2. Characteristics of CZTSe Films and Their Solar Cell Devices
div.div:
Although the four CZTSe films are synthesized following different reaction pathways, they have the same structural properties with the good crystallinity of their kesterite structure. The Raman spectra and XRD patterns for the four CZTSe films, as shown in
Figure
3
a,b, do not show any difference. To compare the crystallinity of the four samples in detail, the values of the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) for the diffraction peaks of the (112) plane for all the CZTSe films are shown in
Figure
3
c. This result signifies that samples A1, A2, and A3 have similar crystallinity, whereas sample A4 has relatively poor crystallinity compared to the others. FE-SEM images of CZTSe films for samples A1–A4 (
Figure S4
) also show a similar trend with the results of FWHM. As shown in
Figure S4
, samples A1, A2, and A3 have a similar grain size with the similar surface roughness, whereas sample A4 has a smaller grain size with higher surface roughness than other samples, as described in
Figure S4
.

div.p: Figure 3. a) Raman spectra and (b) XRD patterns of the CZTSe films synthesized from four samples (A1-p3, A2-p3, A3-p3, and A4-p3) and (c) FWHM of the diffraction peak of the (112) plane in (b).

div.div:
Solar cell devices are fabricated using the four CZTSe films at the same time for one series, and in total, three series are performed in this study. The statistics of the solar cell device parameters for 18 cells per sample are described in
Figure S1
. The best efficient solar cells from each sample for one series are taken, and then, the device characteristics and band gaps are compared, as described in
Figure
4
and
Table
3
. Notably, the device performances of the four samples are significantly different depending on the annealing processes (i.e., the formation pathway), although the structural properties are quite similar in the CZTSe films. In particular, the fill factor (FF) and
V
oc
are remarkably dependent on the annealing process used in the formation of the CZTSe film. Comparing the device parameters of all the samples, the efficiencies are increased from 8.04% (sample A1) to 10.88% (sample A3) as the FF and
V
oc
improved from 51.4 to 64.7% and from 396 to 451 mV, respectively, while the values of short-circuit current (
J
sc
) are similar.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a)
J
–
V
curves, (b) EQE spectra of the best efficient solar cells fabricated using each sample from one series, and band gaps of the CZTSe films (c) calculated from the EQE and (d) measured by PL at room temperature.

div.div:
Table 3. Band Gaps and
J
–
V
Characteristics of the Best Efficient Solar Cells Fabricated Using the Four Samples
a

div.p: The band gaps are extracted from EQE and PL measurements at room temperature for each sample.

div.div:
The band gaps of the four CZTSe films are checked by EQE and PL measurements using the best efficient solar cells of each sample, as described in
Figure
4
b–d. As the band gap extracted from the EQE data can be influenced by variations in the collection efficiency of photons,
(27,28)
PL measurements are also performed. Both sets of data clarify that all four CZTSe films have similar band gaps of ∼1.0 eV. Considering the general phenomenon that a higher
V
oc
in the device results from a wider band gap in the absorber layer, the band gaps detected in this study are unusual. Sample A3 has the highest
V
oc
(451 mV) among the solar cell devices and has the lowest band gaps of 1.01 and 0.99 eV, as extracted from EQE and PL, respectively. Contrary to sample A3, sample A1 has the highest band gap of 1.04 eV from EQE and 1.02 eV from PL, although the solar cell of sample A1 has the lowest
V
oc
(396 mV) of the four devices. Furthermore, the band gaps of samples A1 and A3 are similar, only differing by ∼0.03 eV which indicates that the difference in
V
oc
for the devices in this study comes neither from the band gap nor from the crystallinity of the CZTSe films, as shown in
Figure
3
.

div.h3: 3.3. Defect Analysis and Its Influence on Device Performances
div.div:
The defects in the CZTSe films are confirmed by the AS measurement, as described in
Figures
5
and
S5
. The inflection points (
Figure S5b
) of admittance spectra (
Figure S5a
) are used to construct the Arrhenius plots in
Figure S5c
. The defect energy levels are taken from Arrhenius plots using the following equation ω
0
= 2πν
0
T
2
exp(−
E
t
/
kT
), where ω
0
is the inflection point of the capacitance–frequency spectra,
E
t
is the energetic distance of the defect level from the valence band maximum (
E
V
) or conduction band minimum (
E
C
), and ν
0
is the emission factor.
(29−31)
Defect density of states for each defect energy level (
Figure
5
) is also calculated in accordance with previous literature studies.
(29,32−34)

The results of AS measurements prove that the different device performances come from the different energy levels of the defects in the four CZTSe films. The extracted defect energy levels vary from 36 to 211 meV. The deepest defect (211 meV) is obtained from sample A1, which has relatively deep-level defects (173 and 86 meV). Coincidentally, sample A1 has the worst device performance with the lowest values of
V
oc
(396 mV) and FF (51%). The shallowest defect (36 meV) is observed from sample A3, which has relatively shallow defects (85 and 128 meV), and sample A3 presents the highest device performance with the highest values of
V
oc
(451 mV) and FF (65%), as given previously in
Table
3
. These results signify that
V
oc
and FF improve as the defect energy levels in the CZTSe film become shallower.

Samples A2 and A4 have a similar defect energy level and defect densities of ∼170 meV and ∼4 × 10
16
cm
–3
eV
–1
, respectively, but have different values of
V
oc
and FF. The difference in
V
oc
and FF for samples A2 and A4 seems to come from one additional defect in sample A4, near ∼130 meV, as described in
Figure
5
d-A4. Although the defect at ∼130 meV in sample A4 is shallower than the defect at ∼170 meV, the defect at ∼130 meV seems to influence the device performance of sample A4: a lower
V
oc
and higher FF in sample A4 in comparison with those in sample A2.

To verify the defect types for each defect energy level, the ionization energy levels of the intrinsic defects are considered on the basis of the density functional theory (DFT).
(6,7)
In total, five defect energy levels of 36, ∼85, ∼130, ∼170, and 211 meV are observed from the four CZTSe films. It is obvious that the defects with energy levels of 36, ∼85, and ∼130 meV indicate V
Cu
, Zn
Cu
, and Cu
Zn
defects, respectively, in accordance with other studies.
(6,7,9−11)
Especially, the observation of defects at 36, 85, and 128 meV in sample A3 is well matched with the results for the coexistence of V
Cu
, Zn
Cu
, and Cu
Zn
antisite defects in the Cu-poor/Zn-rich CZTSe phase (Cu
1.74
Zn
1.141
Sn
0.994
Se
4
).
(7)
The defect with an energy level of ∼170 meV can be interpreted as Zn
Sn
, the (−/0) transition energy levels of Cu
Sn
(ionized from neutral to −1 charged) or V
Sn
(−/0) defects,
(6,7)
as described in
Table S1
. The formation energy of the Zn
Sn
defect, however, is much lower than that of the other two expected defects in accordance with the DFT calculation.
(6)
For this reason, the defect at ∼170 meV can be assigned to the Zn
Sn
defect. For the same reason, the defect at 211 meV can also be interpreted as a V
Zn
defect instead of a V
Sn
defect.
(6,34)
The assigned defects and other defects related with the defect energy levels are organized in
Table S2
.

The identification of point defects in each CZTSe film verifies the reason for the highest defect density in sample A3. The V
Cu
and Cu
Zn
acceptor defects in sample A3 may act as carrier sources, which are at a higher concentration than those of the other samples (
Figure
5
), finally indicating that it improves the collection of carriers and the device performance in sample A3. Deep-level defects (V
Zn
and Zn
Sn
) in samples A1, A2, and A4 may act as high recombination centers at the junction region.

div.h3: 3.4. Defect Formation Depending on the Reaction Pathway
div.div:
The defect types in the CZTSe films seem to be determined by the growth rate of the Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases during the reaction pathways. To understand the correlation between defect formation and the reaction pathway, three facts are considered based on previous studies:
(i)
CZTSe can be formed from the selenide phases, not directly from metallic alloys;
(12,15,17−22)
(ii)
The A
B
antisite defect is formed in the A-rich/B-poor composition region;
(6−9)
(iii)
The ZnSe phase is formed in the lower part of the film, separately from the other phases (i.e., the segregation of the ZnSe phase), inducing the Zn-rich and Zn-poor regions in the film during the annealing process.
(17−21)

In total, five types of point defects, V
Cu
, Zn
Cu
, Cu
Zn
, Zn
Sn
, and V
Zn
, can be obtained depending on the reaction pathways, as described in
Table
2
. The Zn
Sn
defect is especially frequently observed in samples A1, A2, and A4 but not in sample A3. According to facts (i) and (ii), the Zn
Sn
antisite defect can be formed with an excess amount of ZnSe and a deficient amount of the Sn–Se phase when the kesterite CZTSe phase starts to form. Here, the Sn–Se phase can form from Cu–Sn, Sn–Zn, and/or metallic Sn alloys.
(1,16,17,21,22)
In other words, if the Cu
6
Sn
5
, Sn–Zn, and/or metallic Sn phases are observed in the film at the point (marked in
Figure
1
) before the CZTSe phase is mainly formed, then the delay or slow growth of the Sn–Se phase in the film is indicated. Coincidentally, the Cu
6
Sn
5
phase is detected at A1-p1, A2-p2, and A4-p1, which represent the intermediate phases before the kesterite CZTSe phase is mainly formed in the film: the CZTSe phase is marked by bold letters at A1-p3, A2-p3, A3-p3, and A4-p2 in
Table
2
to present the large amount of the CZTSe phase in the film. Cu
6
Sn
5
is also detected at A3-p2, but the amount of Cu
6
Sn
5
is smaller than that of the other samples, as confirmed by the enlarged XRD patterns in
Figure S6
. Additionally, the SnSe and SnSe
2
phases are also observed at A3-p2, signifying no chance to replace the Sn in the Zn in the kesterite lattice in sample A3 due to the sufficient amount of the Sn–Se phase, which means that the fast growth of the Sn–Se phase can prevent forming the Zn
Sn
defect.

According to fact (ii), the coexistence of Zn
Cu
and Cu
Zn
defects in sample A3 is contradictory. Fact (iii), however, proves that the Zn-rich and Cu-rich regions can simultaneously appear in the film only when most of the Cu–Sn alloy in the Zn-poor region transforms into the Cu–Se phase in accordance with the literature.
(21)
Similarly, the film taken at A3-p2 shows the separately formed ZnSe (or Zn-rich) phase at the lower part of the film (
Figure S2
). Additionally, the CuSe phase and a small amount of Cu
6
Sn
5
alloy are detected in A3-p2 (
Figure S6
). At the time, if the kesterite CZTSe phase starts to form, the Zn-rich region induces the Zn
Cu
defect, while the Cu-rich region induces the Cu
Zn
defect. Due to the fast growth of the Cu–Se phase, the Cu-rich region can exist instead of a Zn-poor region, inducing the Zn
Cu
and Cu
Zn
defects. It is worth noting that the synthesis of ZnSe with the Cu–Se phase can occur only when the Sn–Se phase exists: a compound of the Cu–Zn–Se phase does not exist in nature.

Contrary to fact (ii), the V
Zn
defect seems to occur because of the excess amount of ZnSe in the film before the CZTSe phase formation. It is well known that the ZnSe phase has the highest stability among the binary selenide phases,
(25)
which means that the ZnSe phase requires higher energy to form than the CZTSe phase if the ZnSe phase cannot react with other selenide phases directly after the ZnSe phase is formed.
(16,22,25)
Similarly, the film taken at A1-p1 includes the ZnSe and CZTSe phases together and trace amounts of the Cu
2
Se and SnSe
2
phases (see
Table
2
). Considering fact (iii), the ZnSe phase is formed on a lower part of the film, and the CZTSe phase is formed on the ZnSe phase, such as a sequence of Mo/(metallic alloys or voids)/ZnSe/CZTSe.
(17)
At the moment, some part of the ZnSe phase near the Mo layer can easily be stabilized due to the trace amounts of the Cu
2
Se and SnSe
2
phases. Therefore, some stabilized ZnSe phase is delayed from participating in the kesterite CZTSe lattice, inducing the V
Zn
defect. Because of the fast growth of the ZnSe phase and the slow growth of the Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases, the V
Zn
is formed in sample A1. The ZnSe phase is also present in the films taken at A2-p2 and A4-p1 (see
Table
2
), but the amount of the ZnSe phase in these two films is small in comparison with the film taken at A1-p1: the diffraction peaks of the ZnSe phase at ∼27° in A2-p2 and A4-p1 (
Figure
2
c,g) show smaller intensities than that of A1-p1 (
Figure
2
a). For this reason, the V
Zn
defect is not observed in samples A2 and A4.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In conclusion, the reaction pathways for the formation of the CZTSe film strongly influence the defect formation in the kesterite CZTSe absorber. The four CZTSe films synthesized under different annealing processes have nearly the same crystallinity and band gap with values of ∼1.0 eV, regardless of their reaction pathways. In contrast to the properties of the films, the efficiencies of the solar cell devices are different, ranging from 8.0 to 10.9% without an antireflection coating. Particularly, the
V
oc
and FF are significantly varied from 390 to 450 mV and from 51 to 65%, respectively, depending on the defect energy levels in the CZTSe films. Five types of point defects (V
Zn
, Zn
Sn
, Cu
Zn
, Zn
Cu
, and V
Cu
) are observed in this study and are shown to correlate with the growth rate of the ZnSe, Cu–Se, and/or Sn–Se phases. From these results, three conclusions can be derived:
(i)
The fast growth of the Sn–Se phase during the annealing process can prevent the formation of the Zn
Sn
defect;
(ii)
The coexistence of Cu
Zn
and Zn
Cu
defects occurs because of the fast growth of the Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases during the annealing process;
(iii)
The formation of the V
Zn
defect is related to the fast growth of the ZnSe phase along with the slow growth of Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases during the annealing process.

The atoms (and their vacancies) that are replaced within the kesterite lattice (i.e., point defects) are determined by the growth rate of the binary chalcogenides, which are components required for the formation of the kesterite CZTSe phase. The results suggest that the formation of the CZTSe film using the CuSe, ZnSe, and SnSe
(2)
phases results in predominantly shallow defects in the CZTSe film, inducing enhanced
V
oc
and FF. In other words, finding a way to grow the Cu–Se and Sn–Se phases faster than (or similar with) the ZnSe phase is the key point to increase the efficiency of CZTSe solar cells.

Effect of solid-H2S gas reactions on CZTSSe thin film growth and photovoltaic properties of a 12.62% efficiency device
Son, Dae-Ho; Kim, Seung-Hyun; Kim, Se-Yun; Kim, Young-Ill; Sim, Jun-Hyung; Park, Si-Nae; Jeon, Dong-Hwan; Hwang, Dae-Kue; Sung, Shi-Joon; Kang, Jin-Kyu; Yang, Kee-Jeong; Kim, Dae-Hwan

We fabricated CZTSSe thin films using optimized SLG-Mo/Zn/Cu/Sn (MZCT) as a stacked structure and described the phenomenon of Zn elemental volatilization using the MZCT stacked structure. We introduced H2S gas to effectively control the S/(S + Se) ratio of the film in the sulfo-selenization process and to suppress Zn volatilization. Unlike during the selenization process, a stable ZnSSe thin film was formed on the precursor surface during the sulfo-selenization process. The formation of the ZnSSe thin film inhibited Zn volatilization, which facilitated control of the thin film stoichiometry and played an important role in crystal growth. In addn., the sulfo-selenization process using H2S forms a grading of the S/(S + Se) ratio in the depth direction in the ZnSSe layer. The ZnSSe layer with this property causes the band gap grading in the CZTSSe absorption layer. Finally, through our optimized annealing process, we realized a world record CZTSSe solar cell with a certified power conversion efficiency of 12.62% and a centimetre-scale (1.1761 cm2) efficiency of 11.28%.

Point defect engineering in thin-film solar cells
Park, Ji Sang; Kim, Sunghyun; Xie, Zijuan; Walsh, Aron
Nature Reviews Materials
(
2018
),
3
(
7
),
194-210
CODEN:
NRMADL
; ISSN:
2058-8437
.
(
Nature Research
)
A review. Control of defect processes in photovoltaic materials is essential for realizing high-efficiency solar cells and related optoelectronic devices. Native defects and extrinsic dopants tune the Fermi level and enable semiconducting p-n junctions; however, fundamental limits to doping exist in many compds. Optical transitions from defect states can enhance photocurrent generation through sub-bandgap absorption; however, these defect states are also often responsible for carrier trapping and non-radiative recombination events that limit the voltage in operating solar cells. Many classes of materials, including metal oxides, chalcogenides and halides, are being examd. for next-generation solar energy applications, and each technol. faces distinct challenges that could benefit from point defect engineering. Here, we review the evolution in the understanding of point defect behavior from Si-based photovoltaics to thin-film CdTe and Cu(In,Ga)Se2 technologies, through to the latest generation of halide perovskite (CH3NH3PbI3) and kesterite (Cu2ZnSnS4) devices. We focus on the chem. bonding that underpins the defect chem. and the atomistic processes assocd. with the photophysics of charge-carrier generation, trapping and recombination in solar cells. Finally, we outline general principles to enable defect control in complex semiconducting materials.

Chen, Shiyou; Walsh, Aron; Gong, Xin-Gao; Wei, Su-Huai

A review of theor. research on defect formation and ionization in kesterite materials, based on new systematic calcns., and compared with the better studied chalcopyrite materials CuGaSe2 and CuInSe2. The kesterite-structured semiconductors Cu2ZnSnS4 and Cu2ZnSnSe4 are drawing considerable attention recently as the active layers in earth-abundant low-cost thin-film solar cells. The addnl. no. of elements in these quaternary compds., relative to binary and ternary semiconductors, results in increased flexibility in the material properties. Conversely, a large variety of intrinsic lattice defects can also be formed, which have important influence on their optical and elec. properties, and hence their photovoltaic performance. Exptl. identification of these defects is currently limited due to poor sample quality. Four features are revealed and highlighted: (i) the strong phase-competition between the kesterites and the coexisting secondary compds.; (ii) the intrinsic p-type cond. detd. by the high population of acceptor CuZn anti-sites and Cu vacancies, and their dependence on the Cu/(Zn+Sn) and Zn/Sn ratio; (iii) the role of charge-compensated defect clusters such as [2CuZn+SnZn], [VCu+ZnCu] and [ZnSn+2ZnCu] and their contribution to nonstoichiometry; (iv) the electron-trapping effect of the abundant [2CuZn+SnZn] clusters, esp. in Cu2ZnSnS4. The calcd. properties explain the exptl. observation that Cu poor and Zn rich conditions (Cu/(Zn+Sn) ≈ 0.8 and Zn/Sn ≈ 1.2) result in the highest solar cell efficiency, as well as suggesting an efficiency limitation in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 cells when the S compn. is high.

This work is an exptl. study of intrinsic point defects in off-stoichiometric kesterite type CZTSe by means of neutron powder diffraction. We revealed the existence of copper vacancies (VCu), various cation anti site defects (CuZn, ZnCu, ZnSn, SnZn, and CuZn), as well as interstitials (Cui, Zni) in a wide range of off-stoichiometric polycryst. powder samples synthesized by the solid state reaction. The results show that the point defects present in off-stoichiometric CZTSe agree with the off-stoichiometry type model, assuming certain cation substitutions accounting for charge balance. In addn. to the known off-stoichiometry types A-H, new types (I-L) have been introduced. For the very first time, a correlation between the chem. compn. of the CZTSe kesterite type phase and the occurring intrinsic point defects is presented. In addn. to the off-stoichiometry type specific defects, the Cu/Zn disorder is always present in the CZTSe phase. In Cu-poor/Zn-rich CZTSe, a compn. considered as the one that delivers the best photovoltaic performance, mainly copper vacancies, ZnCu and ZnSn anti sites are present. Also, this compositional region shows the lowest degree of Cu/Zn disorder. (c) 2018 American Institute of Physics.

Cu-Zn disorder in Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) may be responsible for the large open circuit voltage deficit in CZTS based solar cells. In this study, it was investigated how compn.-dependent defect complexes influence the order-disorder transition. A combinatorial CZTS thin film sample was produced with a cation compn. gradient across the sample area. The graded sample was exposed to various temp. treatments and the degree of order was analyzed with resonant Raman spectroscopy for various compns. ranging from E- and A-type to B-, F-, and C-type CZTS. We observe that the compn. has no influence on the crit. temp. of the order-disorder transition, but strongly affects the activation energy. Reduced activation energy is achieved with compns. with Cu/Sn >2 or Cu/Sn <1.8 suggesting an acceleration of the cation ordering in the presence of vacancies or interstitials. This is rationalized with ref. to the effect of point defects on exchange mechanisms. The implications for reducing disorder in CZTS thin films are discussed in light of the new findings. In this work, photoluminescence (PL), admittance spectroscopy (AS) and drive-level capacitance profiling (DLCP) were performed to analyze the defect properties of a Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) solar cell. Compared to a high efficiency CuInGaSe2 (CIGS) solar cell, the absorber of the CTZS device has larger potential fluctuation which can be attributed to the co-existence of a high concn. of deep acceptor (CuZn) and deep donor (ZnCu) defects. The d. of the interface states in the CZTS device is also orders higher than that in the CIGS device. These high d. defects (both in the bulk and at the CZTS/CdS interface) will induce a large loss in the open-circuit voltage (Voc), resulting in a lower performance of the CZTS device. We suggest that defect control can be a possible soln. to reduce the potential fluctuation induced by acceptors. To overcome the potential fluctuation induced trapping effect for electrons by the ZnCu donors, a graded conduction band similar to CIGS will be good to eliminate electron localization.

Recent advances in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSe) thin film photovoltaics open the possibility for the future industrialization of this technol. Nevertheless, major progresses in CZTSe have been achieved using conventional thermal processing annealing routes (CTP), which rely on time-consuming processes with tubular furnaces, incompatible with the requisites of fast methodologies for the Industry. Changing from conventional to rapid thermal processes (RTP) using halogen lamps as heating method is not at all obvious, since the system becomes kinetically controlled, and the CZTSe formation mechanisms as well as crystn. pathways can drastically change. In this work we present the transfer of our kesterite prodn. baseline (Cu2ZnSnSe4:Ge) from a conventional thermal process using a tubular furnace toward a rapid thermal process using an adapted system, by comparing them and analyzing the differences between both processes in terms of formation mechanisms as well as photovoltaic absorber properties. For this purpose, the rapid annealing process is stopped at different steps, analyzing the compositional, structural, and morphol. properties of the CZTSe absorber at these different stages. Using a combination of XRF, SEM, Raman spectroscopy, and XRD characterization techniques, it is demonstrated that, in contrast to CTP routes, when RTP is used, kesterite is being formed in large amts. in the very early stages. This suggests a fast formation of CZTSe promoted by the higher Se vapor pressure that can be quickly achieved with this methodol. The formation of Kesterite seems to proceed via two competitive reactions (binaries vs ternary compd.). Addnl., the fast reaction obsd. in the system avoids the possible Sn loss in an efficient way. Through the optimization of this RTP treatment a device with 8.3% efficiency has been obtained (the total time of the thermal process is 12 min), comparable with the efficiencies obtained so far with CTP routes. Finally, the consequences of all these changes for the future interpretation of the formation reaction mechanisms of kesterites are discussed.

Solar cells based on Cu2ZnSnSe4 thin film absorber layers have shown promise as an alternative to more mature thin film technologies because they are composed of more earth abundant elements. To increase device efficiencies there is still much to be investigated about its properties, and film and device processing. Rapid thermal processing is a more industrially viable method of forming thin film absorber layers than time intensive conventional thermal processing. However, optimized conditions for conventional processing are not readily transferable to rapid thermal processing. Thermal processing of this material is complicated through loss of volatile components such as Zn and Sn-Se, in addn. to decompn. at elevated temps. In this study the effect of stack order has been investigated for Cu-Zn(O)-Sn precursor stacks selenized by rapid thermal processing to form Cu2ZnSnSe4 thin films. Precursor stack ordering is shown to have significant effects on the film properties, including precursor alloy formation, compn. and elemental loss, morphol., and secondary phase formation and distribution. Optoelectronic properties of devices prepd. from these films also show a dependence on precursor stack order. Most notable is the poor performance of devices with Zn as a bottom layer, due to excessive ZnSe formation at the back contact region. The viability of ZnO as a precursor layer, in place of volatile Zn, is also investigated, and shown to not completely react in the Se atm., leaving residual oxygen in the Cu2ZnSnSe4 films. The best performing device has a conversion efficiency of 4.3%, and uses a stack order of glass/Mo/Sn/Zn/Cu.

In this paper we have presented an in-depth study of effect of metallic precursor stacking order on the growth of the Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin films. The CZTS films were prepd. by employing a two-step process comprising of sequential sputtering of the metal precursors followed by sulfurization. An optimized stacking sequence as well as growth mechanism for obtaining the single phase CZTS has been proposed based on the results of XRD, Raman, XPS, UV-Vis and elec. studies. A combination of Raman anal. and XPS has been carried out to confirm the CZTS phase formation and to detect any minor phases, if present. The occurrence of Raman modes at around 286 and 336 cm-1 for the Zn/Cu/Sn/Cu stack sulfurized at 500 °C indicated the existence of prominent Kesterite CZTS phase. The perfect homogeneous mixing of sequential precursors together with the elemental sulfur was obsd. in the case of sulfurized stack order of Zn/Cu/Sn/Cu, which yielded single phase CZTS films, and further confirmed by high resoln. core level XPS measurements. Stack dependent micro structural features and elemental anal. were also carried out using FESEM attached to EDS. The p-type charge carriers as detected using hot-probe measurement technique and the band-gap energy of ∼1.52 eV as estd. from the absorbance spectrum, suggested that the Zn/Cu/Sn/Cu stack order is most appropriate for realizing single phase CZTS growth using two step method.

Secondary phase formation in a Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 based p-type layer for photovoltaic applications is one of the major problems which must be overcome to improve solar cell efficiency. To better understand the crystn. mechanism of secondary phases in the material system Cu-Zn-Sn-Se, we investigated the selenization of binary metallic layers as a function of temp. The sputtered thin film precursors comprise Cu-Zn, Cu-Sn, and Zn-Sn with different sequence. A total six precursors were studied by time-resolved X-ray diffraction while temp. increased from 30 °C to 550 °C. Selenium had been always deposited on top of the metallic precursors in a sep. thermal evapn. step. The obsd. reaction sequences were shown different results depending on the metals which are in first contact with selenium. From these exptl. results, the mutual affinities of metals are detd., and a way of reducing the ZnSe crystn. is presented. Preferable precursor composed of ternary metallic layers with Se is also suggested in conclusion with respect to a stacking order of the metals.

In recent years, Cu2ZnSn(S1-xSex)4 (CZTSSe) prepd. by a two-step process using metal precursors has been reported to exhibit a relatively high power conversion efficiency, and a high efficiency of 12.5% by two-step process contained via sputtering method was recently confirmed by our group. In this study, we proposed formation mechanisms for the CZTSSe double layer, voids and ZnSSe layer, which were obsd. in the CZTSSe using metal precursor. Due to the persistent dezincification from the metal precursors and preferential reaction between the Zn and chalcogens such as S and Se, almost all Zn is consumed to form the ZnSSe layer; as a result, large voids are produced first under the ZnSSe layer. Cu2Se and SnSe are grown on the ZnSSe layer via migration of the Cu and Sn through the grain boundaries of the ZnSSe layer. Thus, addnl. small voids are expected to form due to the mass transfer of Cu and Sn. Because of the preferentially formed ZnSSe layer and the chalcogenation of Cu and Sn after the mass transfer, a CZTSSe double layer can be formed, and ZnSSe can exist between these CZTSSe layers. Finally, we propose a method based on the formation mechanism to control the voids and secondary phases, which affect the fill factor and output current.

The inclusion of Ge into the synthesis of Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 absorbers for kesterite solar cells has been proven to be a very efficient way to boost the device efficiency in a couple of recent publications. This highlights the importance to elucidate the mechanisms by which Ge improves the kesterite solar cells properties to such a large extent. In this contribution, we first show how controlling the position and thickness of a very thin (10-15 nm) layer of Ge greatly influences the crystn. of kesterite thin films prepd. in a sequential process. Typically, Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) films form in a bi-layer structure with large grains in the upper region and small grains at the back. By introducing Ge nanolayers below our precursors, we observe that large CZTSe grains extending over the whole absorber thickness are formed. Addnl., we observe that Ge induces fundamental changes in the formation mechanism of the kesterite absorber. In a detailed anal. of the phase evolution with and without Ge, we combine the results of X-ray fluorescence, X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy to demonstrate how the Ge influences the preferred reaction scheme during the selenization. We reveal that the presence of Ge causes a large change in the in-depth elemental distribution, induces a stabilizing Cu-Sn intermixing, and thus prevents drastic compositional fluctuations during the annealing process. This finally leads to a change from a tri-mol. towards, mainly, a bi-mol. CZTSe formation mechanism. Kesterite thin films with surprisingly large crystals of several microns in diam. can be fabricated using this approach. The results are related to the increase in device performance, where power conversion efficiencies of up to 11.8% were obtained. Finally, the consequences of the disclosed crystn. pathways and the extension to other chalcogenide technologies are discussed.

Fella, Carolin M.; Uhl, Alexander R.; Hammond, Ceri; Hermans, Ive; Romanyuk, Yaroslav E.; Tiwari, Ayodhya N.
Journal of Alloys and Compounds
(
2013
),
567
(
),
102-106
CODEN:
JALCEU
; ISSN:
0925-8388
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Phase-pure Cu2ZnSnSe4 (CZTSe) layers are necessary for achieving efficient thin film solar cells. This requires the knowledge of intermediate phases and their existence regions during the evolution of the CZTSe phase within its homogeneity range. Here the authors study the growth mechanism of different phases when soln. deposited metal salt precursors are selenized into CZTSe layers. A combination of in situ and ex situ x-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, EDX and SEM at successively increasing substrate temps. is used to track evolving crystal phases. The growth starts with the fast formation of binary Cu-Se phases that are present between 190° and 320°. Overlapping diffraction patterns of CZTSe/Cu2SnSe3/ZnSe phases evolve from 280° onwards and remain until a final temp. of 550°. The ternary Cu2SnSe3 phase coexisting with CZTSe between 340° and 370° is confirmed by Raman spectroscopy and point EDX measurements. No individual Zn or Sn binary phases can be detected. The authors propose the kinetically driven formation mechanism, which starts with the selenization of Cu requiring the lowest activation energy for reaction, and then proceeds via the gradual incorporation of Sn and Zn to yield the final CZTSe phase.

On the formation mechanisms of Zn-rich Cu2ZnSnS4 films prepared by sulfurization of metallic stacks
Fairbrother, Andrew; Fontane, Xavier; Izquierdo-Roca, Victor; Espindola-Rodriguez, Moises; Lopez-Marino, Simon; Placidi, Marcel; Calvo-Barrio, Lorenzo; Perez-Rodriguez, Alejandro; Saucedo, Edgardo

The future development of Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) as an alternative absorber for low cost and high efficiency thin film photovoltaic modules depends strongly on the understanding and control of the formation of secondary phases in this system. With this aim, a detailed chem.-phys. characterization of Zn-rich CZTS films prepd. by sulfurization of metallic stacks is presented, combining x-ray diffraction, Raman, and Auger spectroscopy. Under such conditions a reaction pathway for the formation of CZTS by a solid-liq.-gas reaction with binary compds. as intermediates is proposed. This is supported by the detailed depth-resolved anal. of the films annealed at different temps. and times. The exptl. data support a formation mechanism of CZTS that proceeds rapidly when a eutectic Cu2S+SnS mixt. melts above 480 °C, acting as a flux to react the remaining solid binary phases and sulfur gas present in the annealing atm. During reaction Cu and Sn are completely consumed, while excess Zn segregates towards the back contact regions as shown by a combined Raman-Auger depth-resolved anal. Using the presented thermal treatment process a device with 5.5% efficiency and a max. external quantum efficiency of 79% is obtained.

Herein, a liq.-assisted grain growth (LGG) mechanism for a vacuum-processed Cu2ZnSn(S1-xSex)4 (CZTSSe) absorber that is enabled by the presence of a liq. phase contg. predominantly Cu, Sn, and Se (L-CTSe) is suggested to explain the large grain size of up to ≈6μm obtained at low temps., such as 480°C. In this system, LGG plays a key role in achieving a large grain CZTSSe absorber, but the residual L-CTSe, a key factor in LGG, deteriorates the device performance. L-CTSe residue can possibly remain when using metal precursors for reasons such as local compn. nonuniformity due to the agglomeration of Cu-Sn alloys, uncontrolled Zn volatilization. It is expected that CZTSSe cells with L-CTSe residues have lower efficiency and fill factor than CZTSSe cells without L-CTSe due to the role of L-CTSe as a shunt path and compositional misfit. These tendencies are obsd. in the statistical results. Thus, when synthesizing CZTSSe using a metal precursor in a two-step process, it is considered important to design the precursors to remove unwanted L-CTSe residues and optimization of compn.

Gang, Myeng Gil; Shin, Seung Wook; Suryawanshi, Mahesh P.; Ghorpade, Uma V.; Song, Zhaoning; Jang, Jun Sung; Yun, Jae Ho; Cheong, Hyeonsik; Yan, Yanfa; Kim, Jin Hyeok

Herein, we report a facile process, i.e., controlling the initial chamber pressure during the postdeposition annealing, to effectively lower the band tail states in the synthesized CZTSSe thin films. Through detailed anal. of the external quantum efficiency deriv. (dEQE/dλ) and low-temp. photoluminescence (LTPL) data, we find that the band tail states are significantly influenced by the initial annealing pressure. After carefully optimizing the deposition processes and device design, we are able to synthesize kesterite CZTSSe thin films with energy differences between inflection of d(EQE)/dλ and LTPL as small as 10 meV. These kesterite CZTSSe thin films enable the fabrication of solar cells with a champion efficiency of 11.8% with a low Voc deficit of 582 mV. The results suggest that controlling the annealing process is an effective approach to reduce the band tail in kesterite CZTSSe thin films.

Bandgap of thin film solar cell absorbers: A comparison of various determination methods
Carron, Romain; Andres, Christian; Avancini, Enrico; Feurer, Thomas; Nishiwaki, Shiro; Pisoni, Stefano; Fu, Fan; Lingg, Martina; Romanyuk, Yaroslav E.; Buecheler, Stephan; Tiwari, Ayodhya N.

Knowledge of the absorber bandgap is often needed for assessing the junction quality of a thin film solar cell, for example when computing the open-circuit voltage deficit. The bandgap is typically estd. from the routine measurement of the external quantum efficiency (EQE) of finished devices. However the extn. becomes ambiguous in the case of very thin absorbers, or in presence of bandgap gradients or collection issues of charge carriers. This work reviews several methods for the detn. of the bandgap from EQE measurements and discusses their validity conditions. The numerical results are compared based on exptl. EQE of several different thin film solar cells such as CuInGaSe2, CuInSe2, CdTe, CuZnSnSe and perovskite, and systematic trends are identified. Numerical simulations are also performed to illustrate the behavior of the different bandgap extn. methods in presence of a bandgap gradient and different magnitudes of the exponential tail states.

A method to deduce energy distributions of defects in the band gap of a semiconductor by measuring the complex admittance of a junction is proposed. It consists of calcg. the deriv. of the junction capacitance with respect to the angular frequency of the ac signal cor. by a factor taking into account the band bending and the drop of the ac signal over the space charge region of the junction. Numerical modeling demonstrates that defect distributions in energy can be reconstructed by this method with high accuracy. Defect distributions of polycryst. Cu(In,Ga)Se2 thin films are detd. by this method from temp. dependent admittance measurements on heterojunctions of Cu(In,Ga)Se2 with ZnO that are used as efficient thin film solar cells.

The drive-level capacitance profiling technique was applied to ZnO/CdS/CuIn1-xGaxSe2/Mo solar cell devices, to study properties of defects in the CuIn1-xGaxSe2 film. Properties studied include the spatial uniformity, bulk defect response, carrier d., and light-induced metastable effects. Previous ests. of carrier densities, from C-V profiling, may be significantly overestimated. A defect response previously thought to be located at the interface is obsd. to exist throughout the bulk material. Finally, an IR light-soaking treatment is demonstrated to induce metastable changes in the bulk CuIn1-xGaxSe2 film. Hence, the drive-level capacitance profiling technique provides valuable insights into these films. Herein, the technique itself is fully explained, compared to other junction capacitance methods, and its utility is demonstrated using numerical simulation.

Thermal admittance spectroscopy is used to characterize the trap properties of high-efficiency CuInS2/CdS/ZnO thin-film solar cells. To that aim, the capacitance spectrum is examd. in detail. Non-trap capacitance contributions like freeze-out of free carriers and series resistance are discussed. The dependence of the resistance on the sample area is used to identify its phys. origin. Simulation results of a transmission line model are in good agreement with the spreading resistance of the ZnO window layer. Defect spectra, i.e., the distribution of the deep trapping states in the band gap, are extd. from the admittance spectra. Arrhenius data of the traps are drawn best from the spectrum of conductance vs. temp. The defect spectra do not depend on the buffer layer. Generally, they show a high const. background trap d. with some broad peaks. Two new trap levels at 0.3 and 0.5 eV are found, confirmed by deep level transient spectroscopy and identified as majority carrier traps in the bulk of the p-type CuInS2 absorber. An increasing d. of the trap at 0.5 eV correlates with a decreasing open-circuit voltage.

Tailoring the defects and carrier density for beyond 10% efficient CZTSe thin film solar cells
Li, Jianjun; Kim, SeongYeon; Nam, Dahyun; Liu, Xiaoru; Kim, JunHo; Cheong, Hyeonsik; Liu, Wei; Li, Hui; Sun, Yun; Zhang, Yi
Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells

The defects states and carrier d. of CZTSe absorber layers are two of the crucial factors that decide the photovoltaic performance of CZTSe thin film solar cells. Fine tailoring the defects and carrier d. is a key to push the power conversion efficiency of CZTSe solar cells to a more competitive level. In this work, the phase properties, defect states, and carrier d. of CZTSe thin film are well controlled by fine tuning the ratio of Zn/Sn in the range from 0.75 to 1.27. Capacity-Voltage measurements and Admittance Spectroscopy are used to characterize the carrier d., depletion region width, and defect states of the CZTSe solar cells. The results indicate that the defects states and carrier d. of CZTSe layer are very sensitive to the ratio of Zn/Sn. Combining exptl. results and numerical simulation, the statistic regularities of the photovoltaic parameters of the CZTSe solar cells with different ratios of Zn/Sn is well explained. The increase of VOC of CZTSe solar cells with the ratio of Zn/Sn is related to both the increased carrier d. and the decreased deep level defects states. The decline of JSC of the Zn-rich solar cells is caused by both the shrunken depletion region width and a large barrier caused by ZnSe phase. This barrier is the cause for a low fill factor in the Zn-rich solar cells. Overall, the CZTSe solar cells with a stoichiometric ratio of Zn/Sn=1.02 have favorable defects property and carrier d., thus resulting in the highest photovoltaic efficiency of 10.21%.

We fabricated CZTSSe thin films using optimized SLG-Mo/Zn/Cu/Sn (MZCT) as a stacked structure and described the phenomenon of Zn elemental volatilization using the MZCT stacked structure. We introduced H2S gas to effectively control the S/(S + Se) ratio of the film in the sulfo-selenization process and to suppress Zn volatilization. Unlike during the selenization process, a stable ZnSSe thin film was formed on the precursor surface during the sulfo-selenization process. The formation of the ZnSSe thin film inhibited Zn volatilization, which facilitated control of the thin film stoichiometry and played an important role in crystal growth. In addn., the sulfo-selenization process using H2S forms a grading of the S/(S + Se) ratio in the depth direction in the ZnSSe layer. The ZnSSe layer with this property causes the band gap grading in the CZTSSe absorption layer. Finally, through our optimized annealing process, we realized a world record CZTSSe solar cell with a certified power conversion efficiency of 12.62% and a centimetre-scale (1.1761 cm2) efficiency of 11.28%.

Point defect engineering in thin-film solar cells
Park, Ji Sang; Kim, Sunghyun; Xie, Zijuan; Walsh, Aron
Nature Reviews Materials
(
2018
),
3
(
7
),
194-210
CODEN:

.
(
Nature Research

A review. Control of defect processes in photovoltaic materials is essential for realizing high-efficiency solar cells and related optoelectronic devices. Native defects and extrinsic dopants tune the Fermi level and enable semiconducting p-n junctions; however, fundamental limits to doping exist in many compds. Optical transitions from defect states can enhance photocurrent generation through sub-bandgap absorption; however, these defect states are also often responsible for carrier trapping and non-radiative recombination events that limit the voltage in operating solar cells. Many classes of materials, including metal oxides, chalcogenides and halides, are being examd. for next-generation solar energy applications, and each technol. faces distinct challenges that could benefit from point defect engineering. Here, we review the evolution in the understanding of point defect behavior from Si-based photovoltaics to thin-film CdTe and Cu(In,Ga)Se2 technologies, through to the latest generation of halide perovskite (CH3NH3PbI3) and kesterite (Cu2ZnSnS4) devices. We focus on the chem. bonding that underpins the defect chem. and the atomistic processes assocd. with the photophysics of charge-carrier generation, trapping and recombination in solar cells. Finally, we outline general principles to enable defect control in complex semiconducting materials.

A review of theor. research on defect formation and ionization in kesterite materials, based on new systematic calcns., and compared with the better studied chalcopyrite materials CuGaSe2 and CuInSe2. The kesterite-structured semiconductors Cu2ZnSnS4 and Cu2ZnSnSe4 are drawing considerable attention recently as the active layers in earth-abundant low-cost thin-film solar cells. The addnl. no. of elements in these quaternary compds., relative to binary and ternary semiconductors, results in increased flexibility in the material properties. Conversely, a large variety of intrinsic lattice defects can also be formed, which have important influence on their optical and elec. properties, and hence their photovoltaic performance. Exptl. identification of these defects is currently limited due to poor sample quality. Four features are revealed and highlighted: (i) the strong phase-competition between the kesterites and the coexisting secondary compds.; (ii) the intrinsic p-type cond. detd. by the high population of acceptor CuZn anti-sites and Cu vacancies, and their dependence on the Cu/(Zn+Sn) and Zn/Sn ratio; (iii) the role of charge-compensated defect clusters such as [2CuZn+SnZn], [VCu+ZnCu] and [ZnSn+2ZnCu] and their contribution to nonstoichiometry; (iv) the electron-trapping effect of the abundant [2CuZn+SnZn] clusters, esp. in Cu2ZnSnS4. The calcd. properties explain the exptl. observation that Cu poor and Zn rich conditions (Cu/(Zn+Sn) ≈ 0.8 and Zn/Sn ≈ 1.2) result in the highest solar cell efficiency, as well as suggesting an efficiency limitation in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 cells when the S compn. is high.

This work is an exptl. study of intrinsic point defects in off-stoichiometric kesterite type CZTSe by means of neutron powder diffraction. We revealed the existence of copper vacancies (VCu), various cation anti site defects (CuZn, ZnCu, ZnSn, SnZn, and CuZn), as well as interstitials (Cui, Zni) in a wide range of off-stoichiometric polycryst. powder samples synthesized by the solid state reaction. The results show that the point defects present in off-stoichiometric CZTSe agree with the off-stoichiometry type model, assuming certain cation substitutions accounting for charge balance. In addn. to the known off-stoichiometry types A-H, new types (I-L) have been introduced. For the very first time, a correlation between the chem. compn. of the CZTSe kesterite type phase and the occurring intrinsic point defects is presented. In addn. to the off-stoichiometry type specific defects, the Cu/Zn disorder is always present in the CZTSe phase. In Cu-poor/Zn-rich CZTSe, a compn. considered as the one that delivers the best photovoltaic performance, mainly copper vacancies, ZnCu and ZnSn anti sites are present. Also, this compositional region shows the lowest degree of Cu/Zn disorder. (c) 2018 American Institute of Physics.

Cu-Zn disorder in Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) may be responsible for the large open circuit voltage deficit in CZTS based solar cells. In this study, it was investigated how compn.-dependent defect complexes influence the order-disorder transition. A combinatorial CZTS thin film sample was produced with a cation compn. gradient across the sample area. The graded sample was exposed to various temp. treatments and the degree of order was analyzed with resonant Raman spectroscopy for various compns. ranging from E- and A-type to B-, F-, and C-type CZTS. We observe that the compn. has no influence on the crit. temp. of the order-disorder transition, but strongly affects the activation energy. Reduced activation energy is achieved with compns. with Cu/Sn >2 or Cu/Sn <1.8 suggesting an acceleration of the cation ordering in the presence of vacancies or interstitials. This is rationalized with ref. to the effect of point defects on exchange mechanisms. The implications for reducing disorder in CZTS thin films are discussed in light of the new findings. In this work, photoluminescence (PL), admittance spectroscopy (AS) and drive-level capacitance profiling (DLCP) were performed to analyze the defect properties of a Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) solar cell. Compared to a high efficiency CuInGaSe2 (CIGS) solar cell, the absorber of the CTZS device has larger potential fluctuation which can be attributed to the co-existence of a high concn. of deep acceptor (CuZn) and deep donor (ZnCu) defects. The d. of the interface states in the CZTS device is also orders higher than that in the CIGS device. These high d. defects (both in the bulk and at the CZTS/CdS interface) will induce a large loss in the open-circuit voltage (Voc), resulting in a lower performance of the CZTS device. We suggest that defect control can be a possible soln. to reduce the potential fluctuation induced by acceptors. To overcome the potential fluctuation induced trapping effect for electrons by the ZnCu donors, a graded conduction band similar to CIGS will be good to eliminate electron localization.

Recent advances in Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSe) thin film photovoltaics open the possibility for the future industrialization of this technol. Nevertheless, major progresses in CZTSe have been achieved using conventional thermal processing annealing routes (CTP), which rely on time-consuming processes with tubular furnaces, incompatible with the requisites of fast methodologies for the Industry. Changing from conventional to rapid thermal processes (RTP) using halogen lamps as heating method is not at all obvious, since the system becomes kinetically controlled, and the CZTSe formation mechanisms as well as crystn. pathways can drastically change. In this work we present the transfer of our kesterite prodn. baseline (Cu2ZnSnSe4:Ge) from a conventional thermal process using a tubular furnace toward a rapid thermal process using an adapted system, by comparing them and analyzing the differences between both processes in terms of formation mechanisms as well as photovoltaic absorber properties. For this purpose, the rapid annealing process is stopped at different steps, analyzing the compositional, structural, and morphol. properties of the CZTSe absorber at these different stages. Using a combination of XRF, SEM, Raman spectroscopy, and XRD characterization techniques, it is demonstrated that, in contrast to CTP routes, when RTP is used, kesterite is being formed in large amts. in the very early stages. This suggests a fast formation of CZTSe promoted by the higher Se vapor pressure that can be quickly achieved with this methodol. The formation of Kesterite seems to proceed via two competitive reactions (binaries vs ternary compd.). Addnl., the fast reaction obsd. in the system avoids the possible Sn loss in an efficient way. Through the optimization of this RTP treatment a device with 8.3% efficiency has been obtained (the total time of the thermal process is 12 min), comparable with the efficiencies obtained so far with CTP routes. Finally, the consequences of all these changes for the future interpretation of the formation reaction mechanisms of kesterites are discussed.

Solar cells based on Cu2ZnSnSe4 thin film absorber layers have shown promise as an alternative to more mature thin film technologies because they are composed of more earth abundant elements. To increase device efficiencies there is still much to be investigated about its properties, and film and device processing. Rapid thermal processing is a more industrially viable method of forming thin film absorber layers than time intensive conventional thermal processing. However, optimized conditions for conventional processing are not readily transferable to rapid thermal processing. Thermal processing of this material is complicated through loss of volatile components such as Zn and Sn-Se, in addn. to decompn. at elevated temps. In this study the effect of stack order has been investigated for Cu-Zn(O)-Sn precursor stacks selenized by rapid thermal processing to form Cu2ZnSnSe4 thin films. Precursor stack ordering is shown to have significant effects on the film properties, including precursor alloy formation, compn. and elemental loss, morphol., and secondary phase formation and distribution. Optoelectronic properties of devices prepd. from these films also show a dependence on precursor stack order. Most notable is the poor performance of devices with Zn as a bottom layer, due to excessive ZnSe formation at the back contact region. The viability of ZnO as a precursor layer, in place of volatile Zn, is also investigated, and shown to not completely react in the Se atm., leaving residual oxygen in the Cu2ZnSnSe4 films. The best performing device has a conversion efficiency of 4.3%, and uses a stack order of glass/Mo/Sn/Zn/Cu.

In this paper we have presented an in-depth study of effect of metallic precursor stacking order on the growth of the Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) thin films. The CZTS films were prepd. by employing a two-step process comprising of sequential sputtering of the metal precursors followed by sulfurization. An optimized stacking sequence as well as growth mechanism for obtaining the single phase CZTS has been proposed based on the results of XRD, Raman, XPS, UV-Vis and elec. studies. A combination of Raman anal. and XPS has been carried out to confirm the CZTS phase formation and to detect any minor phases, if present. The occurrence of Raman modes at around 286 and 336 cm-1 for the Zn/Cu/Sn/Cu stack sulfurized at 500 °C indicated the existence of prominent Kesterite CZTS phase. The perfect homogeneous mixing of sequential precursors together with the elemental sulfur was obsd. in the case of sulfurized stack order of Zn/Cu/Sn/Cu, which yielded single phase CZTS films, and further confirmed by high resoln. core level XPS measurements. Stack dependent micro structural features and elemental anal. were also carried out using FESEM attached to EDS. The p-type charge carriers as detected using hot-probe measurement technique and the band-gap energy of ∼1.52 eV as estd. from the absorbance spectrum, suggested that the Zn/Cu/Sn/Cu stack order is most appropriate for realizing single phase CZTS growth using two step method.

A combined in-situ study using x-ray diffraction and DSC during annealing was carried out to study the formation of intermetallic compds. in the stacked elemental layers and to reveal its influences on the crystn. of kesterite Cu2ZnSnSe4. The Mo/Cu/Zn, Mo/Cu/Sn/Zn, Mo/Cu/Zn/Se and Mo/Cu/Sn/Zn/Se stacked films were prepd. with a compn. resembling a typical kesterite Cu-poor and Zn-rich metallic compn. In-situ expts. during annealing of pure metallic stacked films reveal a dynamic intermetallic compds. formation of Cu5Zn8 → CuZn → Cu2Zn → Cu3Zn and Cu6Sn5 → Cu41Sn11. The CuZn and Cu5Zn8 layer formed at the interface of metals/Se may prevent the stacked metallic layers from selenization <320°. On the other side, the dynamic formation of Cu-Zn phases in the stacked films is an origin of a ZnSe gradual formation starting from 320°. Phase anal. suggests that the ternary Cu2SnSe3 phase forms almost immediately after the formation of Cu2Se and SnSe. The formation of Cu2SnSe3 is indicated by the consumption of SnSe by the Cu2Se which occurs at 530-540°. Crystn. of kesterite takes place >540°. On a phenomenol. basis of present results, consequences for the thin film kesterite fabrication for solar cell application are discussed.

Secondary phase formation in a Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 based p-type layer for photovoltaic applications is one of the major problems which must be overcome to improve solar cell efficiency. To better understand the crystn. mechanism of secondary phases in the material system Cu-Zn-Sn-Se, we investigated the selenization of binary metallic layers as a function of temp. The sputtered thin film precursors comprise Cu-Zn, Cu-Sn, and Zn-Sn with different sequence. A total six precursors were studied by time-resolved X-ray diffraction while temp. increased from 30 °C to 550 °C. Selenium had been always deposited on top of the metallic precursors in a sep. thermal evapn. step. The obsd. reaction sequences were shown different results depending on the metals which are in first contact with selenium. From these exptl. results, the mutual affinities of metals are detd., and a way of reducing the ZnSe crystn. is presented. Preferable precursor composed of ternary metallic layers with Se is also suggested in conclusion with respect to a stacking order of the metals.

In recent years, Cu2ZnSn(S1-xSex)4 (CZTSSe) prepd. by a two-step process using metal precursors has been reported to exhibit a relatively high power conversion efficiency, and a high efficiency of 12.5% by two-step process contained via sputtering method was recently confirmed by our group. In this study, we proposed formation mechanisms for the CZTSSe double layer, voids and ZnSSe layer, which were obsd. in the CZTSSe using metal precursor. Due to the persistent dezincification from the metal precursors and preferential reaction between the Zn and chalcogens such as S and Se, almost all Zn is consumed to form the ZnSSe layer; as a result, large voids are produced first under the ZnSSe layer. Cu2Se and SnSe are grown on the ZnSSe layer via migration of the Cu and Sn through the grain boundaries of the ZnSSe layer. Thus, addnl. small voids are expected to form due to the mass transfer of Cu and Sn. Because of the preferentially formed ZnSSe layer and the chalcogenation of Cu and Sn after the mass transfer, a CZTSSe double layer can be formed, and ZnSSe can exist between these CZTSSe layers. Finally, we propose a method based on the formation mechanism to control the voids and secondary phases, which affect the fill factor and output current.
